Key Arguments: The legislation will constrain free speech and open communication among Australians.
The government should not regulate communications between citizens; existing laws are sufficient.
The legislation could be misused by activists and pressure groups to silence opposing views.
High costs for digital media platforms to implement compliance could stifle innovation and operational efficacy.
The definitions of 'harm' and 'hate speech' are subjective and could reinforce societal divisions.
Large penalties could lead to self-censorship and curtail free speech.
Inadequate appeals process for unjust application of regulations.
Concerns about the practicality of combating disinformation from foreign entities.
Notable Quotes: It is simply NOT the job of government to dictate, to enforce or coerce others to enforce restrictions on what Australians can choose to say.
Activists and pressure groups will love this legislation.
Penalties are so large, particularly for misinformation, that fear of application will lead to curtailing free speech in media.
